Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to explore innovative ways to increase the energy conversion efficiency and address the issues limiting wide-spread usage of electromagnetic transduction for harvesting vibration energy. Specifically studied are the methods to increase the conversion efficiency through ingenious designs and fabrication techniques, implement high-energy-conversion ideas with macro- and micro-fabrication technologies including microfabrication processes for permanent magnets and low resistive coils, and demonstrate low-cost energy harvesters with unprecedented conversion efficiency and power level.
The intellectual merit is in the new electromagnetic energy-conversion principle based on arrays of magnets and coils with a magnet array moving in parallel with a coil array in response to vibration input. The new conversion principle has resulted in 270 mW power (into 96 ohm load) out of 0.66 mm vibration amplitude at 65 Hz with a harvester occupying 26 cc and weighing 90 gram. Such a large power is unprecedented, and this research is transformative as it enables hand-held harvesters to be capable of generating 1 100 W out of sub-millimeter vibration amplitude as well as microfabricated counterparts capable of 1 1,000 mW.
The broader impacts are on harvesting ubiquitous vibration energy for alternative energy means and micropower source for electronic or electromechanical systems (removing the need of battery). Students from underrepresented groups including local inner-city high school students will be given opportunities to work on the proposed research. Moreover, local inner-city high schools will be offered working energy harvesters with which the high school students can experiment in their science labs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We designed, fabricated and tested  various vibraton-energy harvesters. First, we developed a macro-scale energy harvester based on hand-wound coils and permanent magnets, and demonstrated that it was capable of powering a detection circuit of a gyrscope within 0.5 seconds of the start of a rotation. Also, we microfabricated the coils with Aluminum in a microfabrication process used for a dome-shaped-diaphragm gyroscope, and paved the foundational technology for monolithic integration of sensor and vibration-energy harvester. Moreover, we explored a microfabrication process with wax-bonded Nd-Fe-B powders, and embedded the magneitc powders in a silicon wafer to fuction as an integrated micromagnet.

For harvesting vibration energy at less than 10 Hz, we fabricated an energy harvester with a floating magnet occupying 75 cc and weighing 22 g (without the acrylic frame), and showed that the floating magnet was completely floating in air without touching the pyrolytic graphite. The energy harvester was tested over 1 - 5 Hz, and was shown to deliver 68 microW into a load of 22 ohm from 2 g acceleration at 3.4 Hz. Also, a sub-miniature energy harvester (1.1 cc and 2.8 g) with a magnet array of four magnets suspended by a laser-machined acrylic spring was fabricated and measured to produce 116 microW into a matched load of 64.5 ohm from 3.6 g acceleration at 160 Hz.

The research has led to (1) invention of novel electromagnetic vibration-energy harvesters and (2) demonstration of very high power output per unit volume or weight. The demonstrated energy conversion efficiency and power level are record-breaking, and consequently, the research will have broad impact on havesting energy from various places and objects for wearable technology, internet of things, sensor networks, etc.
